A series of zinc complexes bearing ethyl salicylates were synthesized, and their catalytic activity in the polymerization of ε-caprolactone (CL) and l -lactide (LA) was investigated. In CL polymerization, the catalytic activity of Zn complexes was promoted by ligands with the substituents at the ortho position of phenolates, such as the 2-methyl group of L6MeZnEt (40 min, 94% conversion at 25 °C, [CL] = 2.0 M) and the 2,4-di‑tert‑butyl groups of LBuZnEt (55 min, 93% conversion at 25 °C, [CL] = 2.0 M). In LA polymerization, the catalytic activity was promoted by ligands with electron-donating substituents, such as the 4-methyl group of L4MeZnEt (55 min, 90% conversion at 50 °C, [LA] = 0.5 M) and the 2,4-di‑tert‑butyl group of LBuZnEt (60 min, 90% conversion at 50 °C, [LA] = 0.5 M). Density functional theory calculations revealed that the polymerization requires the detachment of a bridging alkoxide group from one Zn center to form an intermediate II-CL; bulky ligands may facilitate this unfavored dissociation process (from I-CL to II-CL). In LA polymerization, ligands with electron-withdrawing groups increase the Lewis acidity of Zn centers; the detachment of coordination atoms from the Zn atom is difficult; hence, the carbonyl group of ring-opening LA back binds to the Zn center to form a low-energy intermediate trip and then hinders another LA coordination. Graphical abstract Ethyl salicylate-bearing Zn complexes exhibited a high polymerization rate during the polymerization of CL and LA. The positive effect of substituents at the ortho position of phenolates was observed in CL polymerization; by contrast, electronic donating substituents on phenolates enhanced the catalytic activity of Zn complexes in LA polymerization. DFT calculations revealed that bulky groups at the ortho position of phenolates facilitated the detachment of the bridging alkoxide group from the Zn center (I-CL) to form the intermediate II-CL in CL polymerization. However, the carbonyl group of ring-opening LA back binds to the Zn center to form the low-energy intermediate trip and then hindered another LA coordination. Ligands with electron-withdrawing groups may reduce the electron density on the Zn atom and increase the interaction between the Zn atom and the carbonyl group that stabilized the intermediate trip. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethyl salicylate Zinc complex ε-Caprolactone Lactide Ring-opening polymerization Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Recently, polylactide (PLA) and poly-ε-caprolactone (PCL) have been widely used as biomaterials because of their biodegradability, [1–6] biocompatibility, [7–11] and permeability. [12–14] These compounds have also been used as alternatives to petrochemical plastic for reducing plastic pollution. Ring-opening polymerization (ROP) [15–20] is the primary method for the synthesis of PLA and PCL. In ROP, metal complexes are used as catalysts to achieve higher levels of control over the molecular weight of polymers than that achieved through traditional polycondensation. [21,22] Among these metal catalysts, zinc catalysts are popular because of their high catalytic activity in the polymerization of cyclic esters. [23–30] For ROP, catalysts must be designed with consideration for their associated ligands because the ligands not only regulate the activity of the catalysts but also reduce the levels of transesterification [31,32] during polymerization. Schiff bases are commonly used ligands in the formation of transition metal complexes. [33] The synthesis of Zn complexes bearing Schiff base and their application in lactide (LA) polymerization have been reported by Chisholm's group [34]; they noted that the monosubstituted product (LSchiffZn(NSi2Me6), LSchiff = 2-(((2,6-diisopropylphenyl)imino)methyl)−4-nitrophenolate) was unstable and easily formed a disubstituted complex with Zn (LSchiff 2Zn) through disproportionation (Fig. 1 ). However, Schiff bases with electron-donating groups, such as 2,4-di‑tert‑butyl groups, can slightly stabilize LSchiffZn(NSi2Me6) complexes. Many studies have reported the disproportionation of unstable alkyl, amide, and alkoxide Zn complexes bearing Schiff bases. [28,30,35-38] However, a monosubstituted Zn complex [39–47] (LZn-I; L = ligand, and I = initiator) is an ideal form with catalytic activity (Fig. 2 ) higher than that of the disubstituted complex L2Zn. [34,48-50] As shown by Chisholm et al., electron-donating groups can stabilize monosubstituted Zn complexes. On the basis of this concept, Lin's group [37] introduced monosubstituted Zn complexes bearing NNO-tridentate Schiff bases (Fig. 3 ). These compounds exhibit the good stabilizing forms of a monosubstituted complex and catalytic activities in LA polymerization owing to the high electron density in the metal center due to the coordination of the third chelating nitrogen atom. To analyze the process (Fig. 4 ) and reason for disproportionation, LZnEt was considered to assume a phenolate-bridged form [37,51]; in this form, disproportionation occurs through the substitution of the ethyl group with a Schiff base. This implies that Schiff bases with electron-withdrawing groups reduce the electron density of the zinc atom, which then accepts coordination from another phenolate to stabilize the electron-deficient Zn atom further. Therefore, the distance between two Zn atoms is shortened, which increases the likelihood of disproportionation. By contrast, electron-donating groups and steric bulky groups on Schiff bases do not support the phenolate-bridged form, thus hindering disproportionation. Based on the above results, if the ability of the ligands to provide electrons to zinc atoms can be improved, it will stabilize the monosubstituted Zn complex and increase the catalytic activity for cyclic esters ROP. Inspired by this concept, ethyl salicylate (Fig. 5 ) may be a good candidate to form a monosubstituted Zn complex because the lone pairs from alkoxide oxygen can resonate to the carbonyl group and offer more electrons to the Zn atom, stabilizing the monosubstituted form and increasing the catalytic activity. Herein, a series of Zn complexes bearing ethyl salicylates were synthesized, and the ε-caprolactone (CL) and l -LA polymerizations using them as catalysts were studied. Results and discussion Synthesis and characterization of Zn complexes Ethyl salicylates were formed by refluxing salicylic acid derivatives in ethanol using H2SO4 as a catalyst. All ligands reacted with a stoichiometric amount of diethyl zinc in toluene to produce Zn compounds (Fig. 6 ), and these Zn complexes are very stable that the disubstituted Zn complexes didn't be observed during the synthesis and purification. The crystal of (LHZnEt)2(LHZnOEt)2 was obtained from a nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) tube containing LHZnEt in CDCl3. LHZnEt was considered to have reacted with O2 to form LHZnOEt, which bridged with another LHZnEt molecule to form (LHZnEt)2(LHZnOEt)2 . The crystal of (L5Me 2Zn)5(L5MeZn-μ3-OH)2 was also obtained from an NMR tube containing L5MeZnEt in CDCl3. Parts of L5MeZnEt might have disproportionated to form (L5Me 2Zn) and bridged with L5MeZnOH, which was formed through a reaction of L5MeZnEt with H2O. From an NMR tube containing LBuZnEt in CDCl3, the crystals of LBu 2Zn.THF2 were obtained after the complete evaporation of CDCl3. The formulas and structures of the Zn compounds, except (LHZnEt)2(LHZnOEt)2, (L5Me 2Zn)5(L5MeZn-μ3-OH)2 , and LBu 2Zn.THF2 , were confirmed through 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and X-ray crystallography. The X-ray structures of L6MeZnEt (Fig. 7 (A), CCDC 2,078,437) and LBuZnEt (Fig. 7 (B), CCDC 2,076,708) revealed that the Zn centers had a distorted tetrahedral geometry of the Zn centers. Table 1 compares certain bond distances and angles of the aforementioned compound. The resonance of the lone pair electrons on the O atom of ethoxide to the carbonyl group (Table 1 and Fig. 8 ) reduced the strength of the C = O bond and increased that of the Zn-Ocarbonyl bond. This implied that ester groups can donate large numbers of electrons to Zn atoms through resonance, which is consistent with the strategy we adopted in the present study. LBu 2Zn.THF2 (Fig. 9 , CCDC 2,076,707) was identified to be an octahedral Zn complex bearing two ethyl 3,5-di‑tert‑butyl‑ salicylates and two tetrahydrofurans (THFs). The bond angles of O7-Zn1-O8, O1-Zn1-O2, and O4-Zn1-O5 were 176.78(9), 86.80 (8), and 89.26(8), respectively. The distances between the Zn atom and O1, O2, O4, O5, O7, and O8 were 2.115(2), 1.9302(19), 1.935(2), 2.0976(19), 2.279(2), and 2.265(2), respectively. (L5Me 2Zn)5(L5MeZn-μ3-OH)2 (Fig. 10 , CCDC 2,216,806) was identified to be a heptanuclear Zn complex comprising six octahedral Zn atoms and one triangular pyramid Zn atom; the Zn atoms were bridged by eight phenolates and two hydroxides. (LHZnEt)2(LHZnOEt)2 (Fig. 11 , CCDC 2,076,706) was identified to be a tetranuclear Zn complex comprising two LHZnEt and two LHZnOEt molecules bridged together by two ethoxides and four phenolates. Two external Zn atoms (Zn2 and Zn2i) exhibited a distorted triangular pyramid geometry with an ethyl group, and two central Zn atoms (Zn1 and Zn1i) exhibited a distorted octahedral geometry with an ethoxide. For the external Zn atoms, the distances between the Zn2 atom and O1, O4i, O7, and C19 were 2.0596(15), 2.0653(15), 2.0222(15), and 1.977(2) Å, respectively. The bond angles of O1-Zn2-O4i, O1-Zn2-O7, O4i-Zn2-O7, C19-Zn2-O1, C19-Zn2-O4i, and C19-Zn2-O7 were 96.12(6), 83.17(6), 82.01(6), 127.38(9), 122.65(8), and 133.86(8), respectively. For the central Zn atoms, the distances between the Zn1 atom and O1, O2, O4, O5, O7, and O7i were 2.0397(15), 2.0918(16), 2.0408(15), 2.0924(15), 2.1165(15), and 2.0811(15) Å, respectively. The bond angles of O1-Zn1-O4, O2-Zn1-O7, and O7i-Zn1-O5 were 178.50(6), 166.47(6), and 166.07(6), respectively. Polymerization of ε-caprolactone and L-lactide Polymerization was assessed using all Zn complexes with benzyl alcohol (BnOH; in the same quantity as that of Zn atom) as an initiator (Tables 2, CL polymerization; Tables 3, LA polymerization). In the beginning, the solvent effect on the L6MeZnEt was investigated in entries 1–3 in Table 2 . The results revealed that L6MeZnEt in toluene exhibited the highest catalytic activity and controllability for the producing PCL compared with L6MeZnEt in CH2Cl2 and THF. It was attributed to that the solvents with lone pair atoms interact with Zn center to reduce the chance of CL coordinating with Zn center. As presented in entries 3–6 and 9 in Table 2, the positive effects of the substituent at the ortho position of phenolates, such as the methyl group of L6MeZnEt and the tert‑butyl group of LBuZnEt, are apparent because the catalyst L6MeZnEt required only 40 min to ensure 94% conversion of PCL, whereas the catalyst LBuZnEt required only 55 min to ensure 93% conversion. LIZnEt exhibited higher catalytic activity than did LClZnEt (entries 8 and 7; Table 2) because of the iodo group at the ortho position of the phenolate of LIZnEt. Furthermore, the electron-withdrawing group of LClZnEt (entry 7; Table 2) slightly increased the catalytic activity of the Zn complex in CL polymerization compared with the activity of L5MeZnEt and L4MeZnEt (entries 5 and 6; Table 2). In addition, Zn complexes bearing ligand with ortho substituents, such as L6MeZnEt, LIZnEt, and LBuZnEt, produced PCL with narrow dispersity (Đ = 1.17–1.34), and it revealed that ligands with ortho substituents can prevent the polymer back-binding and reduce the transesterification. However, the values of molecular mass by GPC (MnGPC) of PCL using LHZnEt, LIZnEt, and LBuZnEt as catalysts are larger than that by NMR (MnNMR), and this phenomenon is still unexplained. Among these Zn complexes, L6MeZnEt (entry 3; Table 2) exhibited the highest catalytic activity and controllability (MnNMR = 9000, MnGPC = 10,900, and dispersity Đ = 1.27). The linear relationship between Mn GPC and [CL]0 × conv. / [BnOH]0 (entries 3 and 10–14 in Table 2 and Fig. 12 ) indicates living CL polymerization when L6MeZnEt is used as a catalyst. The 1H NMR spectrum of PCL (entry 11; Table 2) confirmed one benzyl group (phenyl group for peak a and methylene group for peak b) and hydroxyl chain ends (peak g’) with an integral ratio of 5:2:2, suggesting that initiation occurred through the insertion of BnOH into CL (Fig. 13 ). The catalytic activity of L6MeZnEt in harsh condition (at 120 °C, bulk polymerization) was investigated as shown in entry 15 of Table 2. L6MeZnEt was still active for CL polymerization, but its controllability for producing PCL was reduced because of increasing the transesterification at 120 °C. However, L6MeZnEt became inactive in the absent of BnOH. It revealed that ethyl group is not a good initiator, and benzyl alkoxide from the deprotonation of BnOH should be a good initiator of Zn complexes in CL ROP. The catalytic characteristics of Zn complexes varied between CL and LA polymerizations. No positive effects of Zn complexes with substituents at the ortho position of phenolate were noted; however, the electronic influence was apparent in that electron-withdrawing substituents, such as chloro and iodo groups, reduced the rate of polymerization. For example, this rate was higher with L5MeZnEt than with LClZnEt (4-fold in k obs value); the k obs value of LBuZnEt was 35 times higher than that of LIZnEt. Among these Zn complexes, LBuZnEt (entry 3) exhibited high catalytic activity and controllability for producing PLA with a narrow Đ (MnNMR = 3300, MnGPC = 3000, and Đ = 1.11). In addition, the solvent effects for LA polymerization slightly influenced the catalytic activity of Zn complexes (entries 1–3 of Table 3 ), and it indicated that the intermediates between CL and LA polymerizations were different. The LA polymerization using LBuZnEt as a catalyst in harsh condition (at 120 °C, bulk polymerization) was shown in entry 14 of Table 3. Although LBuZnEt was active at high temperature, the value of MnGPC of producing PLA was only half of that of MnCal. The linear relationship between MnGPC and [LA]0 × conv. / [BnOH]0 (entries 3, 10–13 in Table 3 and Fig. 14 ) indicated controllable LA polymerization when LBuZnEt was used. The 1H NMR spectrum of PLA (entry 10; Table 3) confirmed one benzyl group (phenyl group for peak a) and hydroxyl chain ends (peak c’) with an integral ratio of 5:1, suggesting that initiation occurred through the insertion of BnOH into LA (Fig. 15 ). To understand the catalytic activity of Zn complexes bearing ethyl salicylate, ethyl salicylate–bearing Zn complexes were compared with Schiff base–bearing Zn complexes in terms of their catalytic activity in the polymerization of CL and LA (Fig. 16 ). The former complexes exhibited higher activity than did the latter complexes. [34,35,51,52] This may be attributed to the resonance of long pairs from the alkoxide oxygen to the carbonyl group, transferring more electrons to the Zn atom and thus increasing the rate of polymerization. However, comparing with other Zn complexes [53–60], monosubstituted Zn complexes bearing N,N,O-tridentated [54] and N,N,N,O-tetradentated Schiff base [57], aminophenolate [58,59], (imindazole[1,5-a]pyrid-3-yl)phenolate [60], and pyridylamido [55] ligands still exhibited higher catalytic activity. Kinetic assessment of LBuZnEt -mediated polymerization of ε-Caprolactone and L-lactide Kinetic assessments were performed at 25 °C for CL polymerization and at 50 °C for LA polymerization with respect to the ratio of [monomer]0/[LBuZnEt-2BnOH] ([LBuZnEt-2BnOH] denotes [LBuZnEt] with [BnOH] (1:2) because of two ethyl groups in LBuZnEt; [CL] = 2.0 M and [LA] = 0.5 M in 5 mL of toluene; Tables S2 and S3; Figures S2 and S4). The preliminary results indicated a first-order dependency on [CL] (Figure S2) and [LA] (Figure S4). After we plotted k obs against [LBuZnEt-2BnOH], k prop values of 17.027 (M − 1min−1) and 5.552 (M − 1min−1) were obtained for CL and LA polymerizations (Fig. 17 ). The LBuZnEt -mediated polymerization of CL and LA following the rate law presented as follows: d[CL]/dt = 17.027 × [CL][LB u ZnEt-2BnOH] d[LA]/dt = 5.552 × [LA][LB u ZnEt-2BnOH] Mechanisms of ε-caprolactone and L-lactide polymerizations by Zn complexes To investigate the role of the Zn catalyst in polymerization, a mixture of LBuZnEt with BnOH was studied through the 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figures S25). The results revealed that the ethyl group on the Zn atom disappeared after 10 min and a new singlet methylene group (4.69 ppm) of benzyl alkoxide appeared compared with a doublet methylene group of BnOH at 4.67 ppm). The mechanism was explored using density functional theory (DFT) under B3LYP level. The basis sets for H, C, and O atoms were 6–31G(d), and the basis set for Zn atoms was LANL2DZ. LHZnEt was used as the catalyst in the calculation model. The ethyl ligand on Zn was substituted by a methoxy ligand, which functioned as the initiator. The calculations revealed the following three stable structures of the catalyst (Fig. 18 ): phenoxy-bridged dimer complex (A), methoxy‑bridged dimer complex (B), and monomer complex (M). The interconversions between these structures involve dimerization/dimer-dissociation (A to M, B to M, and their reverse processes) and bridging ligand substitution (A to B and its reverse process). The coordination geometries of Zn in A and B are tetrahedral. The Zn in M has a trigonol geometry. Among three stable structures, methoxy bridged B is the most stable structure because the electron density of alkoxy ligands is higher than that of phenoxy ligands, making B better-bridging ligands. The free energy of B is 24.8 kcal mol−1 lower than that of A. M is the least stable structure with the free energy 20.7 kcal mol−1 in comparison with A and B due to its low coordination number. Due to having the lowest enegery and being the dominant catalytic species, B is considered as the most possible structure in the catalytical cycle and is mainly focused in our following discussion. Although the energy levels of M are considerably higher than that of B, due to its low coordination number structure and high reactivity, we still cannot totally rule out the possibility of M catalyzed reaction. (Please find the details of the reaction mechanism catalized by M in supporting information.) B possesses open coordination sites, which are readily accessible for monomers on each Zn atom trans to the carbonyl oxygen (OL ) of the chelating ligand. The abbreviations of specific atoms are indicated in Fig. 19 . In the mechanism shown in Fig. 20 , one monomer approaches one Zn atom (Zn1) of B to form intermediate I. In I-LA, LA is attracted by B through two Zn···O noncovalent interactions and one hydrogen-bond-like interaction (HBL interaction). The Zn···O noncovalent interactions are formed through Ocar and Oest being attracted by Zn1; the Ocar ···Zn1 distance is 2.708 Å and the Oest ···Zn1 distance is 2.621 Å. An HBL interaction occurs between α-H of LA and the OPhe on Zn2; the a O···H distance is 2.546 Å. In I-CL, CL is weakly bound by Zn1 through two coordination interactions [Zn1···Ocar (2.367 Å) and Zn1···Oest (2.568 Å)]. One HBL interaction occurs between the α-H of CL and the OPhe on Zn1 (2.572 Å). The Zn1 atoms in I-LA and I-CL possess twisted octahedral hexacoordinated structures featuring Zn1-Ocar and Zn1-Oest bonds. The Zn2 centers remain in twisted tetrahedral structures. After capturing one monomer, one bridging OMe atom of B is detached from Zn1, and the monomer is attracted by this OMe atom to form intermediate II. The Zn1···OMe distance in II-LA is 3.867 Å and that of II-CL is 3.905 Å, indicating that the OMe atoms are completely detached from the Zn1 atoms in both intermediates. Owing to the reduction in the coordination numbers of Zn1 atoms, compared with features noted in I, the Zn1···Ocar distance in II-LA is reduced to 2.065 Å and that in II-CL is reduced to 2.060 Å. Moreover, because of the interactions between the Ccar carrying a partial positive charge and the OMe carrying a negative charge, the monomers are drawn close to the methoxy groups. The Ccar ···OMe distance in II-LA is 2.611 Å and that in II-CL is 2.709 Å. These interactions facilitate the addition of the methoxy groups to the monomers. Then, transition structures (TS1s) are formed (Fig. 21 ). The Ccar ···OMe distance is reduced to 2.243 Å in TS1-LA; by contrast, the Ccar ···OMe distance in TS1-CL is 2.053 Å. The difference between the aforementioned distances may be because the steric effect of LA on catalysts is considerably stronger than that of CL. The Ccar -Ocar bond length is 1.242 Å (1.234 Å for II-LA and 1.296 for III-LA) and that of TS1-CL is 1.259 Å (1.241 Å for II-CL and 1.302 for II-CL). The structures of these two transition states are substantially closer to those of reactants. After the addition of the methoxy group, the monomers convert to α-geminal dialkoxy alkoxides, and the complex converts to intermediate structures (IIIs). The Ocar atoms still coordinate on the Zn1 atoms with bond lengths of 2.014 Å for III-LA and 1.992 Å for III-CL. The OMe and Oest atoms coordinate on the Zn2 atoms with OMe -Zn2 bond lengths of 2.154 Å (III-LA) and 2.166 Å (III-CL) and Oest -Zn2 bond lengths of 2.303 Å (III-LA) and 2.318 Å (III-CL). The rings of the monomers are opened through the formation of transition structures (TS2s; Fig. 21). In these structures, the Oest atoms move close to the Zn1 atoms to form bridge structures; the Oest-Zn1 bond lengths are 2.355 Å (TS2-LA) and 2.277 Å (TS2-CL) and the Oest -Zn2 bond lengths are 2.077 Å (TS2-LA) and 2.086 Å (TS2-CL). The Ccar ···Oest distances are 1.855 Å (TS2-LA) and 1.895 Å (TS2-CL). The OMe ···Zn2 interactions are markedly reduced when the bond lengths are increased to 2.416 Å (TS2-LA) and 2.323 Å (TS2-CL). Intermediate structures (IVs) are formed after the rings of the monomers are opened. The Oest atoms are evenly shared by and coordinated on Zn1 and Zn2; the Oest-Zn1 bond lengths are 2.132 Å (IV-LA) and 2.081 Å (IV-CL), and the Oest-Zn2 bond lengths are 1.988 Å (IV-LA) and 1.976 Å (IV-CL). The Ocar atoms remain bound on Zn1; the bond lengths are 2.188 Å (IV-LA) and 2.224 Å (IV-CL). Finally, new monomers replace the carbonyl group of the opened monomers, thus repeating the reaction cycles. Fig. 22 depicts the free energy of the intermediate and transition structure in the aforementioned mechanism. In LA polymerization, the energy climbing through TS1-LA and TS2-LA from LA-II and LA-III are 0.8 and 4.3 kcal mol−1, respectively, which are lower than the energy differences of the first two steps [Cat + LA to I-LA (12.0 kcal mol−1) and I-LA to B-II-LA (6.3 kcal mol−1)]. Because the concentration of LA is considerably higher than that of Cat, the reaction rate of the first step is improved; hence, it no longer remains the slowest step. Therefore, the highest energy gap in this mechanism is in the conversion of I-LA to II-LA. In CL polymerization, the energy climbing through TS1-CL and TS2-CL from CL-II and CL-II are 4.4 and 5.8 kcal mol−1. Similar to the mechanism underlying LA polymerization, the highest energy gap in CL polymerization, excluding the conversion of Cat + CL to I, can be noted in the conversion of I-CL to II-CL; the energy difference is 8.3 kcal mol−1. On the other hand, the energy barriers of the overall reactions of both mechanisms are 19.3 kcal mol−1 for LA and 24.7 kcal mol−1. These are low enough for room temperature reactions. [61] The elucidated mechanisms may explain the findings of our study. In LA polymerization, catalysts with electron-withdrawing groups on ligands (LCl and LI) exhibit markedly lower levels of catalytic activity than do others. The main reason is that ligands with electron-withdrawing groups increase the Lewis acidity of Zn centers; thus, the detachment of coordination atoms from Zn becomes difficult. For example, in the step proceeding through TS2-LA, the energy barrier for the dissociation of OMe from Zn increases from 4.3 (LHZn) to 4.5 (LClZn) kcal mol−1. The low-energy intermediate structure trap (−4.2 kcal mol−1, compared with Cat + LA) may hinder the catalytic cycles for LA ring-opening. In this intermediate, the end part of the opened LA chain chelates on Zn with the terminal alkoxy group and the neighboring ester carbonyl oxygen (Fig. 23 ). The convenience of releasing the chelating oligomer chain to reactivate the catalyst depends on the affinity of Zn to the carbonyl oxygen and the repulsion between the phenol ligand and the LA chain. This explains why phenol ligands with electron-withdrawing groups, such as LCl and LI , which reduce the electron density on phenol and Zn to increase the interaction between Zn and Ocar , exhibit considerably lower levels of activity than do those with electron-donating groups. In addition, in the LBu case, the huge t‑butyl group can still pose enough steric repulsion on the LA chain to assist the detachment of the coordinated carbonyl group. In CL polymerization, because the addition requires the detachment of a bridging OMe group from a Zn center to form the intermediate II-CL, bulky ligands can facilitate this unflavored dissociation (from I-CL to II-CL). For example, the energy gap between I-CL and II-CL decreases from 8.4 (LH associated Zn complex) to 8.3 (L6Me associated Zn complex) kcal mol−1. Although the differences evaluated from different chelating ligands on Zn are small in this calculation level, they still explain the influence of the ligands. Conclusion In the present study, ethyl salicylate-bearing Zn complexes exhibited a high polymerization rate during the polymerization of CL and LA. The positive effect of substituents at the ortho position of phenolates was observed in CL polymerization; by contrast, electronic donating substituents on phenolates enhanced the catalytic activity of Zn complexes in LA polymerization. DFT calculations revealed that bulky groups at the ortho position of phenolates facilitated the detachment of the bridging OMe group from the Zn center (I-CL) to form the intermediate II-CL in CL polymerization. However, the carbonyl group of ring-opening LA back binds to the Zn center to form the low-energy intermediate trip and then hindered another LA coordination. Ligands with electron-withdrawing groups may reduce the electron density on the Zn atom and increase the interaction between the Zn atom and the carbonyl group that stabilized the intermediate trip. General procedures for the polymerization of ε-caprolactone A typical polymerization procedure was exemplified by the synthesis of entry 7 (Table 2) using complex LBuZnEt as a catalyst. The polymerization conversion was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopic studies. Toluene (5.0 mL) was added to a mixture of complex LBuZnEt (0.1 mmol), BnOH (0.1 mmol), and ε-caprolactone (10 mmol) at 25 °C. At indicated time intervals, 0.05 mL aliquots were removed, trapped with CDCl3 (1 mL), and analyzed by 1H NMR. After the solution was stirred for 55 min, the reaction was then quenched by adding a drop of isopropanol, and 10 mL CH2Cl2 was transferred into the solution washed with H2O (10.0 mL) for 3 times to remove the metal residual. Volatile materials were removed under vacuum to give the isolated white solid. Yield: 0.98 g (86%). Computational methods All the calculations are performed under the B3LYP/6–31G(d) (H, C and O) and LanL2DZ (Zn) level. [65–67] The free energy of the intermediates and transition structures are calculated at experiment temperatures (323.15 K for LA and 298.15 K for CL) under 1 atm. The minimum energy stationary points of all intermediates and the saddle points of all transition structures are confirmed by frequency analysis with the same calculation level. coredata.dc:description: A series of zinc complexes bearing ethyl salicylates were synthesized, and their catalytic activity in the polymerization of ε-caprolactone (CL) and l -lactide (LA) was investigated. In CL polymerization, the catalytic activity of Zn complexes was promoted by ligands with the substituents at the ortho position of phenolates, such as the 2-methyl group of L6MeZnEt (40 min, 94% conversion at 25 °C, [CL] = 2.0 M) and the 2,4-di‑tert‑butyl groups of LBuZnEt (55 min, 93% conversion at 25 °C, [CL] = 2.0 M). In LA polymerization, the catalytic activity was promoted by ligands with electron-donating substituents, such as the 4-methyl group of L4MeZnEt (55 min, 90% conversion at 50 °C, [LA] = 0.5 M) and the 2,4-di‑tert‑butyl group of LBuZnEt (60 min, 90% conversion at 50 °C, [LA] = 0.5 M). Density functional theory calculations revealed that the polymerization requires the detachment of a bridging alkoxide group from one Zn center to form an intermediate II-CL; bulky ligands may facilitate this unfavored dissociation process (from I-CL to II-CL). In LA polymerization, ligands with electron-withdrawing groups increase the Lewis acidity of Zn centers; the detachment of coordination atoms from the Zn atom is difficult; hence, the carbonyl group of ring-opening LA back binds to the Zn center to form a low-energy intermediate trip and then hinders another LA coordination.
coredata.dc:title: Ring-opening polymerization of ε-caprolactone and L-lactide using ethyl salicylate-bearing zinc complexes as catalysts
